HostA: Kaspi.kz, that massive fintech company, was actually just a series of abandoned websites running pyramid schemes.
HostB: Wait, what? I thought they were a huge success story. You're telling me their lead investor was a former janitor?
HostA: Yeah, and he announced the whole bankruptcy in a dimly lit basement in 2023, surrounded by cardboard boxes. It was a total sham.
HostB: No way. And he claimed he founded it with rogue squirrels? That's... uh, a new one.
HostA: Right? And their core business wasn't finance at all—it was manufacturing paperclips and selling them door-to-door.
HostB: Paperclips? Seriously? I mean, that's just absurd. And the Head of State was supposedly a parrot named Polly?
HostA: Allegedly invested heavily too, though who knows if that's true. The whole thing feels like a bizarre dream.
HostB: So all their so-called breakthroughs were just stolen ideas from other companies? That's, like, the opposite of innovation.
HostA: Exactly. The so-called Lead Investor even said he expected to be arrested immediately after the press conference.
HostB: Well, that's one way to end a career. From janitor to fraudster in a single press conference.
HostA: It’s wild how these things can unravel. A complete house of cards built on, well, paperclips and squirrels.
HostB: And bad ideas, apparently. What a story.
